title-group.article-title: Are Some Outside Directors Better than Others? Evidence from Director Appointments by Fortune 1000 Firms*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2005 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: I analyze 1,493 first‐time director appointments toFortune1000 boards, during 1997–99, to investigate whether certain outside directors are better than others. Reactions to director appointments are higher when appointees are CEOs of other companies than when they are not. CEOs are more likely to obtain outside directorships when the companies they head perform well. Well‐performing CEOs are also more likely to gain directorships in organizations with growth opportunities. Because, for these firms, a large portion of their value hinges upon realizing their growth potential, I conclude that CEOs are sought as outside directors to enhance firm value.

fn.p: This paper is based on chapter 2 of my Ph.D. dissertation at New York University. I thank my committee members, Jay Hartzell, David Yermack, and Larry White (chairman), for important recommendations and many hours of counsel. I also benefited from helpful comments from Raquel Benbunan, Diane Covkin, Kevin Hallock, Rob Hansen, Bill Greene, Kose John, April Klein, Anil Shivdasani, Steve Slezak, Richard Sylla, an anonymous referee, and seminar participants at Cornell University, SUNY Binghamton, University of North Carolina, University of Miami and New York University. I gratefully acknowledge a Willensky Fellowship from NYU, which provided financial support for this research. An earlier version of this paper was titled “Do Directors who are CEOs of Other Firms Enhance Firm Performance?” All remaining errors are my own.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The board of directors of a publicly traded corporation plays an important role in monitoring managers and making financial decisions. Although corporate governance policy groups advocate board independence, no laws require firms to have independent boards. Nevertheless, the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE, since 1978) and the NASDAQ (since 1989) require companies whose stock is traded on their exchanges to have at least two outside directors on their corporate boards. This requirement suggests that some unaffiliated monitoring is considered necessary to safeguard or advance shareholders' interests.

The evidence in Rosenstein and Wyatt (1990) supports this conjecture; they report positive cumulative abnormal returns (CARs) upon the appointment of outside directors to corporate boards. However, they find no clear evidence indicating that outside directors of any particular occupation are perceived more or less positively than others. Similarly, although Agrawal and Knoeber (1999) show that firms more likely to be involved in litigation are also more inclined to appoint lawyers to their boards and companies that depend heavily on government regulation are more likely to appoint politicians, they do not find that the appointment of outside directors of either profession enhances company performance. Further, Klein (1998) argues that firms cannot improve performance by adding or removing outside directors of any particular occupation from their boards.

If companies cannot enhance performance by including or excluding specific kinds of outside directors from a board, then why are CEOs of other firms the most widely recruited executives for outside directorships?1Under what conditions do firms appoint a CEO instead of a non‐CEO as an outside director? Are CEOs perceived more favorably by shareholders than non‐CEO directors? If so, why? If firm performance in fact is enhanced due to the appointment of a CEO as an outside director, are there long‐term benefits of such appointments? This paper examines these questions.

A key result in this paper is consistent with Fama (1980) and Fama and Jensen's (1983) view of the managerial labor market. As these authors suggest, I show that CEOs indeed are rewarded with outside directorships when the firms they head perform well. The results presented here also show that firms distinguished by independent boards, high levels of institutional ownership, or high growth opportunities are more likely to appoint as an outside director an individual who currently is a CEO of another firm. I interpret these results to indicate that well‐governed firms and those desiring to exploit their growth potential, seek the expert advice of well‐performing CEOs of other companies. An alternative explanation is that CEOs are less likely to accept directorships in firms in which the likelihood of continued future good performance is low, so acceptance of outside directorships signals the market that the prospects of the appointing firms are favorable.2

News accounts provide evidence supporting the notion that certain firms can benefit when well‐known successful executives join their companies. For example, the stock of Sunbeam Corporation gained $6.125, closing at $18.625, a 49% increase, on news that the former chief at Scott Paper Company, Albert Dunlap, had been hired to recharge the consumer products and appliance maker.3Similarly, Antilla (1993) reports the abrupt market reaction to the appointment of John Sculley, a former chairman for Apple Computer Inc., to the board of Spectrum Inc. Shares of Spectrum soared by $3.50, to $11.125, giving Spectrum a market valuation of $789 million by the end of the day, even though the company had never closed a fiscal year with a gain since its founding in 1984, and that the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) had recently investigated Spectrum for stock manipulation.

I studied whether market reactions to appointment of outside directors reveal that some outside directors are perceived more favorably than others. For this purpose, I performed an event study and found that cumulative abnormal returns associated with the appointment of new outside directors are strongly related to whether the appointee is the CEO of another firm. Appointments of outside directors are associated with significantly positive CARs when the appointee is a CEO elsewhere, but with insignificantly negative CARs when the appointee is a non‐CEO, suggesting that outside CEOs are considered sources of superior managerial talent and unique expertise. I conducted multivariate tests to examine the possibility that the positive stock‐price reactions to the announcement of CEOs as directors may be due to the prestige of the appointee, the education of the new director, the size of the appointing firm, or other board changes. The results of these multivariate analyses indicate that my initial finding is robust to controls for the appointee's reputation, education, and the type of director replaced. In addition, I find that CEOs from commercial banks, on average, are perceived to be more valuable than CEOs from other organizations. Furthermore, I also find the positive effects of the appointment of an outside CEO to be more pronounced in smaller, rather than in larger, firms and in firms that are smaller than those headed by the appointees. The analyses also indicate that appointment of external CEOs as outside directors has long‐term positive performance benefits for the appointing firms.

In contrast with other results, I document negative share‐price reactions among companies in which their own CEOs accept outside directorships, particularly if these CEOs have not yet attained retirement age. This result suggests that shareholders may perceive outside directorships as impediments to these CEOs' effectiveness at their home firms. On the other hand, it is also possible that the acceptance of directorships among relatively youthful CEOs may signal unfavorable conditions at their home firms.

The paper proceeds as follows. Section II reviews the relevant literature, develops the hypothesis, and discusses alternative hypotheses. Section III describes the sample selection and variable definitions. Section IV analyzes the characteristics of firms that appoint outside CEOs as outside directors. Section V studies market reactions to director appointments. Section VI investigates stock‐price reactions in the home boards of CEOs who accept outside directorships. Section VII investigates whether any long‐term changes in firm performance are associated with the appointment of outside CEOs as directors. Section VIII concludes.

fn.p: Bacon and Brown (1974) assert that, because of the experience and prestige they acquire while running their firms, successful CEOs are in great demand as members of outside boards. In a survey of outside directors ofFortune1000 firms, Lorsch and MacIver (1989) find that 63% of outside board members are CEOs of other firms. Survey evidence indicates that, among major U.S. companies, CEOs top the list of preferred candidates to fill open directorship positions (Pellet1998). This evidence is corroborated by Ferris, Jagannathan, and Pritchard (2003), who observe that, among all top executives, CEOs are regularly those with the greatest number of external directorships.

If CEOs can sit on the boards of flourishing companies to improve their own profiles, the direction of causality would be reversed. To address sample selection concerns of this type, I conduct an event study in Section V.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: CEOs as Outside Directors
sec.p: Academic research on the role of outside directors who are CEOs of other firms is thin. Studies in this area have focused on the reasons CEOs take on outside directorships and not on the motives of the firms that appoint these executives. For instance, board directorships can be a source of prestige and business contacts, which may induce CEOs to accept outside directorships (Mace1986). However, monetary rewards and perquisites do not appear to significantly attract highly compensated CEOs to outside directorships (Booth and Deli1996). It is more likely that, as CEOs increasingly delegate more authority to their eventual successors, they find more time to devote to directorships with other firms (Vancil1987). Similarly, CEOs serving in companies with fewer growth opportunities or in corporations consisting primarily of assets in place may be more available to sit on external boards (Booth and Deli1996). In this section, I discuss a number of hypotheses to explain why boards may seek CEOs as outside directors.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Managerial Talent
sec.p: Economists have long noted that in certain kinds of economic activity there is a concentration of output among a few individuals and, therefore, a strong tendency for market size and reward to be skewed toward the most talented people engaged in the activity (Rosen1981). Laderman (1994); for example, reports that, during the period of 1989–93, mutual fund managers who were Ivy League graduates generally outperformed their non‐Ivy counterparts, while Chevalier and Ellison (1999) show that mutual fund managers who attended higher‐SAT undergraduate institutions tended to produce higher risk‐adjusted excess returns.

Fama (1980) and Fama and Jensen (1983) suggest that prior accomplishments can be used as a measure of an individual's talents and executives of well‐performing firms are rewarded with directorships in the director labor market. There is empirical evidence to support rewards and penalties suffered by directors in the director labor market due to their firm performance. Gilson (1990) reports that CEOs of financially distressed firms are less likely to receive outside directorships, as are CEOs of companies that reduce dividends (Kaplan and Reishus1990). Brickley, Linck, and Coles (1999) find that, unlike CEOs who completely leave their firms after retirement, CEOs who stay as outside directors after retiring generate 10.9% higher annual abnormal stock returns and 2.0% higher annual accounting returns.

These studies suggest that firms like to retain on their boards outside chief executives with proven managerial talent and established performance records in order to improve their own performance. In this context, there is some evidence supporting the idea that individuals with superior abilities and track records may also add value to different firms. For example, in a study of 82 publicly traded firms between 1911 and 1912, De Long (1991) finds that membership on a firm's board of directors by a partner in J.P. Morgan and Co. added about 30% to the common stock equity value. De Long suggests that monitoring by Morgan partners made these firms more profitable.4

It is possible that the unique set of skills acquired by CEOs set these individuals apart from other executives. Thus, such unique managerial talent is sought by firms looking to appoint outside directors to their boards and recognized by investors as value enhancing. Given this conjecture, I put forth the managerial‐talent hypothesis. This hypothesis is based on the idea that highly talented well‐performing CEOs are sought for board service at other companies.

fn.p: Ramirez (1995) suggests that, aside from improved monitoring, affiliation with the Morgan house also added liquidity to the associated companies, which was not available to other comparable firms.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: CEO Support
sec.p: In addition to the managerial talent hypothesis, there are other competing explanations for the appointment of CEOs as outside directors. For example, Westphal and Zajac (1997) advance a social exchange “CEO‐support” hypothesis to account for the decision to offer a directorship to a CEO. They find that CEO‐directors are more likely to induce changes in an external board if they experienced such changes at their own firms. They argue that incumbent CEOs defer to other CEOs to prevent being badgered in their own firms and CEOs are likely to join a board only if they are able to support their fellow CEO. The CEO‐support hypothesis and the managerial‐talent hypothesis need not be mutually exclusive, as the unique talent that a CEO‐director brings to the appointing firm may be his ability to induce a change he has already experienced in his own firm.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Balance of Power
sec.p: If certain directors, such as other CEOs, are likely to support incumbent CEOs, then, as Hermalin and Weisbach (1997) show in their balance‐of‐power model between the CEO and the board, CEOs try to acquire influence over the selection of new directors. Such power can be obtained by exerting influence over the nomination of new directors. In this context, Shivdasani and Yermack (1999) document significantly negative CARs upon the inclusion of outside directors to a board when the CEO is on the nominating committee. They argue that investors view appointments to the board to be of lesser quality when the CEO is involved in the selection process. Despite the negative perception, CEOs may seek to elect sympathetic directors to leverage their power in the boardroom, a motive that may explain the appointment of external CEOs onto corporate boards.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Certification and Supply of Directors
sec.p: If there is a market for highly skilled directors and the supply of qualified executives is limited, then it would be difficult for some firms to retain CEOs to serve as directors on the board. This may happen because these individuals are busy on their own boards or it could be costly for them to accept an outside directorship. Booth and Deli (1996) enumerate the costs that may accrue to CEOs from directorships; they argue that these costs are likely to dissuade CEOs from accepting outside appointments.5Despite the difficulties, certain firms may seek to add CEOs as outside directors because of the endorsement benefits accrued by finding one willing to serve. Companies may seek to attract a well‐known CEO to serve on their board because the acceptance of a directorship may serve as a “certification” of the future prospects of the firm. This would be true of firms with attractive growth prospects as well as for firms where analyst coverage is scant. I refer to this conjecture as the certification hypothesis.

Based on these hypotheses, I investigate the characteristics of firms that appoint CEOs as outside directors, whether or not such appointments are perceived by investors to enhance the value of the appointing firm. I also examine the effect these appointments have, if any, on the stock price of the outside CEOs' home firms and whether the appointments are related to any lasting effect on the appointing firm's performance.

fn.p: Costs may include exposure to shareholder lawsuits or discipline on their own boards for non‐value‐maximizing behavior.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Data Description and Sample Selection
sec.p: I searched the Lexis/Nexis data retrieval system for newspaper stories and press releases to track director selections for all publicly traded firms in the 1998Fortune1000 list, during the 3‐year period 1997–99. Because financial firms (SIC codes 6000–6999) and utilities (SIC codes 4900–4999) operate in more regulated environments, I do not include directors appointed to these firms in the sample. I imposed two other sample selection conditions. First, I excluded appointments that were announced simultaneously with other major company news or first revealed in the firm's proxy statement. Second, I did not record announcements of directors re‐elected to their positions or those that involve multiple director appointments. This procedure generates a final sample of 1,493 first‐time appointments at 432 companies.6

Information for each director appointment was collected and organized from proxy statements and annual reports and, when necessary, complemented with records available fromThe Million Dollar DirectoryandWho's Who in Finance and Industry. Characteristics of board appointees appear intable 1. Each director is classified according to the following criteria. Full‐time employees of the firm are categorized as “insiders” (363 appointments). Individuals closely associated with the appointing company, retired employees, those having family or business connections with the firm other than their directorships, or having interlocking directorships with the CEO are designated “gray” directors (158 appointments). The information presented intable 1indicates that outside directors are generally older than their colleagues from other classifications. Also, 32.9% of all gray appointments and 62.9% of all outside appointments are CEOs of other firms. Out of the 52 gray CEO appointees 42 are interlocked with the home CEO and 13 have commercial ties with the home firm.7Thus, about 6.3% of all CEOs in the sample are reciprocally interlocked. This figure is comparable to that in Hallock (1997), who finds that about 8% of all CEOs in his sample are reciprocally interlocked with another CEO. In addition, about 52.5% of gray directors hold either MBA or law degrees, compared to 51.5% of outsiders and 42.6% of insiders. Directors from all classifications own very little equity in the firms that appoint them.

I read proxy statements filed for 1997, 1998, and 1999, for each of the 432 companies in the sample. From these filings, I obtained data on board size, board composition, board compensation, and firm ownership. While the number of directorships held by my sample CEOs may point toward a possible bias, it may simply reflect the tendency of boards to appoint more CEOs as directors in recent years. Supporting this conjecture,figure 1illustrates that the percentage of CEOs appointed as outside directors increased every year through the 3‐year period. In my sample, this increase holds regardless of whether the CEO is gray and even though the total number of grays appointed increases from 1997 to 1998 but decreases from 1998 to 1999. In addition, for each CEO in my sample, we record all directorships held in publicly traded firms. In contrast, Ferris et al. (2003) count directorships only if the directorship firm is in their sample, a criterion which is likely to miss the full set of board seats any one director holds. Fig. 1.—

Table 2also presents sample correlations between the percentage of directors who are CEOs of other firms and other variables. These correlations provide no clear indications of what types of firms select CEOs as outside directors or whether outside directors are perceived positively by shareholders. Significantly, greater percentages of outside CEOs are more likely to be present in large firms (as proxied by total assets), indicating, perhaps, that large firms establish bonds by appointing outside CEOs to their boards or that bigger companies are better able to attract and appoint such executives. Higher percentages of outside CEO‐directors are also found in firms with larger overall percentages of outside directors and companies with high levels of stock ownership by institutional investors. This association may indicate that outside‐CEO directorships are more likely to be found in firms with strong corporate governance. Percentages of outside CEO‐directors are likewise larger in companies with strong growth opportunities (as proxied by the market‐to‐book ratio which we calculate following Smith and Watts1992) and are smaller in underperforming firms (as proxied by return on assets, ROA).8A possible explanation for this finding is that outside CEOs favor participation in firms with expansion prospects but not in troubled organizations. Alternatively, it may be harder for underperforming firms to attract CEOs to serve as directors on their firms.

The complex association between the percentage of outside CEO‐directors and other variables does not suggest clearly whether appointing these executives enhances firm value, nor does it illuminate the characteristics of companies that appoint CEO‐directors to their corporate boards. Therefore, I now turn to a multivariate analysis.

The results of Models 1 and 2 show that appointees are more likely to replace outgoing directors of the same classification than directors from different classifications. This finding is similar to that reported by Shivdasani and Yermack (1999). Other results indicate that independent boards and companies with high institutional ownership are more likely to appoint outside directors and less likely to appoint gray directors, suggesting that firms with institutional activism favor monitoring by outsiders to reduce potential conflicts of interest. In contrast, ownership by insiders is inversely related to the likelihood of independent outside appointments and positively related to the appointment of gray directors, suggesting that insiders may prefer less intense monitoring.

fn.p: Using the ratio of R&D expense to sales, a frequently used proxy for growth opportunities, does not alter the results.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Appointments of Independent and Gray CEOs
sec.p: Booth and Deli (1996) raise the possibility that executives of different firms may join each other's boards to better bond a commercial relation and that CEOs are more likely to join external boards when their own firms have fewer growth opportunities. Brickley et al. (1999) show that the likelihood of a CEO of being asked to serve on another firm's board as an outside director is positively correlated with the ROA of the CEO's own firm. While these studies focus on the characteristics of the appointee's home firm, the characteristics of the appointing firm's board are largely unknown. Thus, conditioning on boards appointing outside directors, I examine the likelihood that the new appointee is an outside CEO. Similarly, I condition on the board appointing a gray director and study the likelihood that the new appointee is a gray CEO. Probit models of these choices are reported as Models 3 and 4 oftable 3, respectively.

Results indicate that the level of institutional ownership and board independence, characteristics often associated with strong corporate governance, are positively related to the appointment of outside CEOs but unrelated to the appointment of gray CEOs. Remarkably, the appointment of CEO‐directors is inversely related to the percentage of CEOs serving as outside directors in a board. One possible explanation for this result is that firms are reluctant to appoint directors who replicate skills other board members already have. Coefficient estimates also indicate that the likelihood of being asked to serve on another firm's board as an outside director is not associated with the appointing firm's ROA.10This variable yields a negative but statistically insignificant coefficient in all models.11In contrast, the findings indicate that outside CEOs, but not gray CEOs, are more likely to get directorships when their own firms perform well. This result supports the managerial‐talent hypothesis to the extent that the performance of a CEO's own firm proxies for his or her abilities. In addition, the result is consistent with the assertions in Fama (1980) and Fama and Jensen (1983) that executives of well‐performing firms are rewarded with directorships in the director labor market.

I also observed that being a current CEO of a large firm positively affects the probability of appointment. This result suggests that the increased visibility from heading a large company may help CEOs obtain more directorships. As with Booth and Deli (1996), the likelihood of obtaining an outside directorship is inversely related to the growth prospects of the CEO's own firm. However, the likelihood of obtaining an outside directorship is positively related to the growth prospects of the appointing firm. These results are significant for outside CEOs but not for gray CEOs. Because the value of a firm is contingent on its ability to realize its growth potential, I interpret these results to indicate that the expert advice of external CEOs is sought to enhance firm performance.

While these results support the managerial‐talent hypothesis, the results are consistent with alternative explanations as well. It is possible that, under strong governance structures, CEOs get support from fellow CEOs or the balance of power between the CEO and the board is adjusted following the appointment of a CEO as an outside director. These explanations and the managerial‐talent hypothesis, of course, are not mutually inconsistent and may contribute to the patterns reported intable 3.

fn.p: Gilson (1990) indicates that certain kinds of outside directors are appointed to boards during periods of financial distress. I repeated the estimation to examine whether some appointments are more likely if the firm is experiencing financial distress. For this purpose, I included Altman's (1968)Z‐score as an independent variable. Although all coefficient estimates are negative, indicating that the probability of an appointment increases with decreasingZ‐scores, neither is significant. This result should be interpreted with caution and may be due to the fact that my sample consists of generally healthy firms.

I used other accounting ratios, such as return on sales and asset turnover, to proxy for performance, as well as different measures of performance changes during the years prior to the appointment. The coefficient estimates for these proxies are not significant.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Univariate Analysis
sec.p: The analyses presented in the previous section suggest that outside CEO‐directors are likely to be appointed in situations where knowledgeable counsel may be needed to fully exploit growth opportunities and thereby enhance firm performance. However, the preceding analyses do not really reveal if there are differences in the perceived managerial quality of the various director appointees. Moreover, if there is a market for managerial human capital, CEOs may choose to sit on the boards of successful companies to raise their own profiles. If this is the case, the direction of causality is reversed. The event‐study approach removes sample‐selection problems of this type.

I examined investor reactions to the announcement of every outside and gray director appointment. I estimated cumulative abnormal stock returns over the 3‐day period from the day before the announcement until the day after, following the standard event‐study methodology (Dodd and Warner1983). I estimated market model parameters α and β from 1 year of trading data prior to the event window. To control for possible bias on the market model parameters, I re‐estimated the CARs with simple net‐of‐market returns in place of market model returns. This estimation generates similar results to those calculated with the market model parameters.

Panel B oftable 4reports CARs for appointments of gray directors. I obtain negative and significant mean and median CARs for appointments of all gray directors. This result suggests at least two interpretations. Gray directors may be met with negative reactions because they are perceived to be more likely to have conflicts of interest and, thus, less likely to be effective monitors. Alternatively, shareholders may associate these appointments with negative corporate performance or other problems, as gray director appointments, particularly those of accountants or lawyers, are more likely to take place during periods of financial distress (Gilson1990).

I evaluated the CARs across subgroups of directors who are CEOs of other firms. The second and third columns of panel A oftable 4report results for these analyses. Investors appear to welcome outside CEO‐directors, for their reactions are significantly positive, with estimates of 0.72% for the mean and 0.54% for the median CAR, respectively. Reactions for non‐CEO outside directors are negative but statistically insignificant. However, botht‐test and Wilcoxon rank‐sum tests indicate that CARs are significantly higher for appointments of CEOs as outside directors than appointments of non‐CEOs. Reactions to appointments of non‐CEO gray directors are negative and significantly lower than those for gray CEOs. In fact, reactions to the appointment of gray outside‐CEOs are positive and close to zero. This finding suggests that the negative reaction to a gray director selection may be ameliorated if the appointee is a CEO.

The results indicate that investors perceive outside directors who are CEOs of other firms more favorably than their non‐CEO counterparts. These findings alleviate concerns about CEOs sitting in well‐performing firms to raise their own profiles. In addition, these findings are consistent with a number of explanations. First, it is possible that positive reactions signal shareholder perceptions of superior managerial talent. Second, it is also possible that shareholders respond favorably to the appointment of the outside CEO because this executive is considered less likely to be coopted by the CEO. As Hermalin and Weisbach (1997) discuss, such an appointment may alter the balance of power of the board. Third, as discussed by Westphal and Zajac (1997), markets may welcome the appointment of an outside CEO if the appointee is viewed as one who would support the incumbent CEO in inducing needed changes. Again, these explanations are not mutually inconsistent with the managerial‐talent hypothesis and may all play a role in the findings presented intable 4.

Other situations may be likely to elicit the results presented. For example, consistent with the certification hypothesis, the appointments may be viewed by investors as “celebrity” endorsements by well‐known CEOs and, hence, reflect favorably on the appointing firms. By accepting outside directorships, CEOs in effect are ratifying a positive outlook for the appointing firms. This phenomenon could be especially beneficial for small or new firms that generate little coverage by analysts, as endorsements by well‐known CEOs may dissipate uncertainty about future prospects. Moreover, smaller firms may be able to capture more rents from outside CEO‐directors, because the marginal product of these executives may be higher in these firms. Therefore, it is important to consider the size of the appointing firms in the analysis.

The business press provides evidence supporting the idea that small ventures can benefit from appointments of successful CEOs to their boards. For example, when Yellowave Corp., a small California Internet concern, announced that 3Com's CEO, Eric Benhamou, was joining its board of directors, Yellowave's shares climbed 118% to a high of $24 a week later (Sandler and Weintraub2000). This outcome suggests that it is important to account for both the reputation of the appointee and the size of the firm when studying investors' reactions to director appointments.

A different scenario might also account for the event study results. These favorable investor reactions could be due simply to changes in board composition, such as the replacement of a gray director or a move toward board independence, rather than to the fact that the appointee is an outside CEO. Consequently, it also seems appropriate to account for the information content and the type of board change when evaluating the market reaction to director announcements. I address these issues next, by examining the CARs in a multivariate context.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Multivariate Analysis
sec.p: I performed a multiple regression analysis of the CARs reported intable 4to study whether the results are driven by certain characteristics of the appointee, of the appointee's own firm, and of the appointing firm.

The first model oftable 5reports the estimations of a multivariate analysis conducted for the market model CARs for the entire set of gray and outside director appointments. I use a (0, 1) variable to indicate if the appointee is the CEO of another company. The analysis includes a number of controls to examine the possibility that factors other than the appointee being an outside‐CEO generate the positive and significant stock price reactions estimated. To investigate if these reactions are driven by board composition changes, I controlled for the type of director replaced (if any). I also included the natural log of the appointing company's sales to control for firm size. To consider the possibility that the favorable share‐price reactions obtained may be due to an endorsement by a prominent individual, I follow other studies and used the number of additional board seats held by the appointee as a measure of an individual director's reputation (see, e.g., Shivdasani1993). Other controls include the industry‐adjusted ROA to proxy for firm performance; dummy variables to indicate if the incumbent CEO is of retirement age (between 62 and 66), following Hermalin and Weisbach (1988); an indicator for the CEO serving on the nominating committee, following Shivdasani and Yermack (1999); the appointees' educational background; and other occupations. Commercial bankers who take on directorships may bring a unique set of skills to the appointing boards. Booth and Deli (1999) find that commercial banks in the United States tend not to be represented on the boards of companies to which they lend in order to avoid conflicts of interest. They therefore argue that, when commercial bankers are appointed to boards, they are selected to provide boards with bank debt market expertise rather than to monitor the bank's lending relationship. This market expertise and the absence of conflicts of interest are likely to make these directors better monitors. To isolate the incremental impact of appointing a CEO of a commercial bank as an outside director, I constructed a (0, 1) dummy variable that takes the value of 1 if the appointee is the CEO of a commercial bank and the value of 0 otherwise.12

The results of the multivariate analyses are in agreement with the univariate tests. The key independent variable I use to indicate if the director appointee is the CEO of another firm has a positive and significant relationship to the abnormal returns. The coefficient estimates indicate that CARs are approximately 1.2% higher for appointments involving outside CEOs. Furthermore, the CEO‐appointee indicator is robust to the inclusion of a number of controls added to address concerns about board composition changes, director reputation, and the size of the firm. In fact, none of these controls appears to be significantly associated with the estimated stock price reactions.

As in Shivdasani and Yermack, the CEO in the nominating committee is inversely associated with the market reactions, CARs are about 1.1 lower in this circumstances. Other results indicate that the academic backgrounds of appointees, controlled in the estimation by the inclusion of both an MBA and a law degree indicator, are not significantly associated with the CARs obtained. This finding suggests that certain unique skills attained by CEOs are perceived more favorably than business, law, or academic degrees. One notable exception is observed for the (0, 1) dummy indicating whether the appointee is the CEO of a commercial bank. For this variable, the coefficient is positive and significant. These results imply that, although CEOs of any type are perceived as valuable outside directors, CEOs from commercial banks, on average, are perceived to be even more valuable. The source of this incremental value might come from better skills (perhaps in bank debt markets, as in Booth and Deli1999) that are expected to lead to improvements in cash‐flow and shareholder value or from reduced uncertainty about the stability of the firm given that, according to Kroszner and Strahan (2001), commercial bankers tend to sit on the boards of large stable organizations.

fn.p: The banker dummy variable in the model takes the value of 1 if the director is a commercial banker, an investment banker, or an insurance industry executive and the value of 0 otherwise.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Further Controls
sec.p: To further investigate if the impact of the appointment of an outside CEO varies with firm size and the current success of the CEO, I conditioned on the appointee being a CEO and repeated the analysis using the CEO‐related CARs as the dependent variable in the second and third models oftable 5. I used the industry‐adjusted ROA of the appointed CEO's firm as a proxy for the appointee's current success.

I used two proxies for firm size. In Model 2, I include the difference in size between the CEO's home firm and the size of the appointing company as an independent variable in the estimation. For this purpose, I define Δsize as the appointee's firm size minus the size of the appointing firm.13In Model 3, I replace the firm size variable for (0, 1) firm‐size‐decile indicators for the bottom 50% of the sample firms, with the tenth decile representing the smallest 10% of the sample firms.14Because the identity of the appointees' home boards is known when they are CEOs, I include the appointee's own industry‐adjusted ROA as an independent variable in Models 2 and 3.

The estimations in Models 2 and 3 oftable 5continue to support the managerial‐talent hypothesis. CEO‐related CARs are positively associated with the appointee's own firm performance. As for firm size, the estimations in Models 2 and 3 suggest that smaller firms are more likely to benefit from the appointment of a CEO. In Model 2, the Δsize variable is positive and significant; while in Model 3, the coefficients for the eighth, ninth, and tenth firm‐size deciles, representing the smallest 30% of observations, are positive and significant. These results are consistent with the certification hypothesis, where CEOs of larger firms play an endorsement role that reduces the uncertainty about future prospects of smaller firms. The positive reactions that accrue to smaller firms may be their recompense for successfully attracting a CEO willing to serve on their boards. Alternatively, appointing companies may derive greater benefits from outside CEO‐directors coming from larger firms, rather than from those who head companies of similar size. This may happen because the marginal product of labor of a CEO of a large firm is likely to be large in small firms.

fn.p: I am able to construct the Δsize variable for 579 appointments for which total sales, Compustat data item 12, is available.
Using all 10 deciles in the estimation does not alter the results.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Stock Price Reactions in the Outside CEOs' Own Firms
sec.p: The preceding analyses indicate that investors react favorably to the appointment of outside CEOs as directors, but the analyses do not reveal whether the shareholders of these CEOs' home firms also favor their chief executives having board responsibilities outside their firms. To investigate this issue, I studied investor reactions to the home firms of CEOs appointed as outside directors atFortune1000 firms. I repeated the analysis performed in Section V and computed cumulative abnormal returns for their home firms over a 3‐day period running from the day before the announcement until the day after. I eliminated announcements that coincide with any other major company news. This screening procedure allows me to identify 252 usable announcements of active CEOs as outside directors during 1997–99.

According to state corporation laws, CEOs and other corporate officers have fiduciary responsibilities to their firm's shareholders. Therefore, if accepting outside directorships may have negative effects on shareholder wealth, CEOs are not likely to accept these appointments. However, in some circumstances, CEO directorships may promote shareholder value. For example, directorships may help CEOs advance the strategic objectives of their own firms by bonding relationships with suppliers or key clients (Booth and Deli1996). Mace (1986) indicates that CEOs are more likely to accept directorships as they delegate more and more responsibility to their eventual successors. Acceptances of outside directorships thus may signal an increased likelihood of CEO retirement, news that might meet with unfavorable reactions if the home firms are performing well or if CEOs are not of retirement age. This discussion suggests that significant differences among CEOs and their firms may affect the likelihood of accepting directorships, and such differences should be controlled for when studying investor reactions to appointments of CEOs as outside directors.

With these caveats in mind, I evaluated the CARs across subsamples of CEOs of retirement age prior to proceeding to a multivariate analysis. For appointments of CEOs who have not reached retirement age, reactions are significantly negative, with magnitudes of −1.12% and −0.82% for the mean and median CAR, respectively. In contrast, announcements involving CEOs aged 62 or older generate mean and median CARs that are not significantly different from zero. However, botht‐test and Wilcoxon rank‐sum tests indicate that CARs are significantly lower for appointments of CEOs who have not reached retirement age, compared to appointments of CEOs who have. The results suggest that, when CEOs have reached retirement age, investors are aware that these executives are likely to continue their careers as outside directors (Brickley et al.1999). Hence, investors appear to be indifferent to announcements of directorships involving CEOs of retirement age.

In contrast, appointments involving CEOs who have not reached retirement age are met with unfavorable investor reactions. One interpretation is that investors fear such directorships may induce CEOs to be less involved at their own firms. Alternatively, it is possible that the early acceptance of directorships may be thought to signal unfavorable news at these CEOs' home firms, as executives might be more likely to voluntarily leave their organizations in anticipation of problems.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Multivariate Analysis
sec.p:
Table 7reports my estimations of a multivariate analysis conducted for the market model CARs for the set of CEOs appointed outside directors. I use a (0, 1) variable to indicate if the appointee has not yet reached retirement age. The analysis includes a number of controls to examine the possibility that factors other than retirement age generate the negative and significant stock‐price reactions that I estimate. To investigate if these reactions are driven by firm performance, I include the firm's industry‐adjusted return on assets for both the current and previous year in the estimation. I also incorporate the natural log of the company's sales to control for firm size in the regression. To consider the possibility that the negative share‐price reactions obtained may be due to the compensation of the CEO, I add the natural log of his total compensation in the regression. I also include the market‐to‐book ratio, as a proxy for the growth opportunities of the firm, as well as the number of other directorships held by the CEO. Because CEOs coming from commercial banks generate significantly positive CARs on the receiving firms, I include a (0, 1) commercial‐bank indicator in the regression to examine whether the appointment also elicits significant CARs on the sending firm.15

Consistent with the univariate results, the CEO not‐of‐retirement‐age indicator has a negative and statistically significant relationship with investor reactions. The estimated coefficient indicates that CARs are approximately 3.1% lower in situations when CEOs who have not reached retirement age are appointed outside directors.

CARs are also lower and significant for large firms and for companies that perform well or have substantial growth opportunities. This last result is consistent with those in Booth and Deli (1996), who indicate that CEOs are less likely to accept directorships when their own firms have substantial growth opportunities. I interpret the results to imply that, if the home firm has substantial growth opportunities or is performing well, outside CEO directorships are perceived to be detrimental to shareholder wealth. Most of the other explanatory variables—board size, board independence, CEO compensation, CEO ownership, CEO tenure, the number of directorships, whether the CEO is also the board's chairman or belongs to the founding family—do not yield significant coefficients. sec.label: VII.
sec.title: Long‐Term Changes in Performance Surrounding Director Appointments
sec.p: The preceding empirical analyses document the short‐term wealth effects of new director appointments to the boards ofFortune1000 companies. In this section, I examine whether there exist a long‐term performance impact due to the appointments of CEOs as outside directors. Here, firm performance is measured by changes in operating income before depreciation (OIBDA) in the years surrounding the director appointment.17I divided OIBDA by the book value of total assets (TA) to control for differences in size across firms. The advantage of this approach is that it provides evidence based on accounting information rather than on market data. The drawback, however, is that the analysis does not control for whether other major board or company change took place during the period. These limitations could yield biased results.

I excluded from the sample all firms where Compustat data are not available for at least 2 years before and 1 year after the director appointment. For those companies with two or more director appointments during the fiscal year, only one observation was recorded. These criteria reduce the initial sample to 990 observations, including the appointments of 267 insiders, 108 grays, and 615 outsiders. About 35% of the gray appointees were CEOs of other firms, while just over 58% of the outside appointments were CEOs at other companies. Other observations were lost in the years following the appointment.18

Table 8reports median and mean differences in OIBDA/TA over four different windows: (−3, −1), (−1, +1), (−1, +2), and (−1, +3). Even though I computed both unadjusted and industry‐adjusted changes in OIBDA/TA, I concentrate the discussion on the industry‐adjusted results because these changes are adjusted for cross‐sectional industry differences and therefore isolate the effect of the director appointment.19

Accounting performance improvements related to the appointments of gray CEOs are observed for at least 2 years following the appointments.

In summary, the results intable 8suggest that the investor reactions documented intable 4for the appointment of directors who are CEOs of other firms at least partially reflect expectations of real improvements in operating performance. However, because of the limitations of this analysis, the evidence in this section should not be viewed as conclusive but as supportive of the other results.

sec.label: VIII.
sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Because highly qualified human capital is likely to give organizations a competitive edge, understanding how companies retain their top‐level decision makers should be of extreme importance to financial economists. In fact, Zingales (2000) and Rajan and Zingales (2000) observe the growing importance of human capital in determining firm value.

This paper investigates the proposition that some outside directors may possess greater managerial abilities than others. I begin by noting that the actual retention patterns of outside directors appear to differ from those implied by the existing literature. If, as some researchers indicate, the choice of a particular type of director has no bearing on firm value, then it is puzzling to observe that outside CEOs are the most coveted individuals to fill directorships in publicly traded firms.

I analyze data for a large sample of major U.S. firms to investigate the characteristics of firms that appoint outside and gray directors to their boards as well as the characteristics of the appointees. The results indicate that all outside director appointments, including those of outside CEOs, are likely to occur in firms associated with strong corporate governance. However, I also find that outside CEOs are particularly likely to join the boards when firms have significant growth opportunities. To the extent that the value of a firm is contingent upon realizing its growth potential, this result suggests that these individuals are retained to provide the knowledgeable counsel needed to successfully improve firm performance. Significantly, this interpretation is consistent with the idea that outside CEO‐directors are sources of unique expertise, industry contacts, and business acumen, and therefore are of greater value than outside directors of other occupations. In addition, consistent with Fama (1980) and Fama and Jensen's (1983) view of the director labor market, I find that CEOs are rewarded with outside directorships when the firms they head perform well.

I also show that stock‐price reactions to director appointments are significantly higher for outside CEO‐directors than for others. Moreover, a multivariate analysis reveals that the positive and significant association between the appointment of outside CEO‐directors and the CARs estimated is robust to numerous controls. One interpretation of this result is that investors perceive outside CEO‐directors more positively than non‐CEO outside directors. This perception may arise because of the unique skill that CEOs can deliver to firms looking to exploit their growth potential or because the appointing companies may be able to derive substantial rents from these directors. The analysis shows that, on average, CEOs from commercial banks are perceived to be more beneficial than CEOs from other companies. I also find the positive effect of the appointment of an outside CEO‐director is more pronounced in smaller firms than in larger ones or as the difference in size between the appointee's firm and the appointing firm increases. This finding supports the notion that the appointed CEO “certifies” the future prospects of a small firm or, alternatively, that a small firm is rewarded for its ability to find a CEO willing to serve on its board. I also provide evidence suggesting that appointments of CEOs as outside directors have positive long‐term performance effects.

In contrast with the other results, I find negative stock‐price reactions at the home firms of CEOs who accept outside directorships before they have reached retirement age. Event‐study results indicate that investors dislike early directorships by CEOs, possibly because they fear these CEOs will spend less time maximizing their own shareholders' wealth. A multivariate analysis reveals that investor reactions are more negative when the CEOs' own firms have substantial growth opportunities. However, reactions are more positive for sending firms that are commercial banks. I interpret this result to indicate that directorships by bank CEOs help promote new business for commercial banks.

Overall, my analysis supports the notion that reputation is a key characteristic in the corporate director labor market for selecting outside directors. The results indicate that investors react favorably when proven talent joins a firm but react unfavorably when such talent is drawn away. I find that companies with growth prospects are especially likely to appoint well‐performing CEOs of other firms as outside directors. Because, for these firms, a greater fraction of its value is contingent upon achieving its growth potential, I conclude that appointments of CEOs are sought to enhance firm value.
